How can we ever know the size of populations of extinct people or for that matter the population ratios between modern humans and Neanderthals? We always hear that the Neanderthals had too small a population to be viable but what evidence is there for this if the fossil record for both modern humans and Neanderthal is so limited? Also - how do we know when a people went extinct? If it is only because the most recent fossil finds are from a certain date, we can never know that we just haven't yet found something from a later period. After all, an absence of evidence is not evidence of absence.

The claim that Neanderthals were a poor survival candidate is actually the oldest theory making it dogma and dogma rarely dies. If they were such poor survivors why did they "hang on" for half a million years? To put it into perspective we need to survive another 250,000 years just to math the Neanderthal's success. Science requires evidence except when it comes to established dogma and there's no reason to believe they died out due to being poorly adapted to survive. We base all this on a limited number of bones which in dogma terms means there weren;t many of them but even that makes no sense given we keep finding early cousins, the Denisovans are an example so absence of evidence does NOT mean absence. Even the Neanderthal range is often determined by a few bones which means we have no idea how wide spread they were. We need them to be inferior to us or we might die out. Things look bleak about us making it another 200 years and if we do it will be a radically smaller population since we burned through most of our resources. Now who is a better survivor? A far better question would be not why they died out but what made them so successful? Our very survival may depend on that question.

I'd have to see much more evidence for the cause of the end guadelupian mass exticntion before I consider it a cut and dry case, especially since the existance of said mass extincion is a recent discovery. It was said that it was in close proximity in time to the permian extinction, and that it was almost certainly caused by volcanism. It was once thought without question that the permian extinction was caused by volcanism, but it has since come under question with more accurate dates for surrounding events in geologic time. Now we now know that the dates of the permian extinction and the volcanism that suposedly caused it don't line up perfectly with each other in a way that would imply direct causality. Perhaps we will find the same for the end guadelupian mass extinction when more robust research becomes available. Research on the end guadelupian mass extinction is in its infancy and I'd be surprised if our understanding of it doesn't change in the near future.

I kind of stopped digging into this but long before the big guns ever publicly suggested this I suggested that genetic washing was occurring on a usitnet group. (Most of you have never even heard of that. It appears to have vanished from the net without a trace.) That is when a big population comes in contact with a small population their genes can be diluted very quickly.

It has later been shown that Europe is a genetic sink. That is waves of migrants have entered Europe and each wave has reduced the amount of DNA present from those already there. This has happened many times. It wasn't until the European Expansion into the Americas that much European DNA made it out of Europe and since most European populations are now failing reproduction the odds appear to be good that will have nominal long term impact on the world population.

There has also been some selection against some Hsn DNA and in favor of some Hsn DNA. Since our ability to understand what the code says even when we can read it is very limited doing more than guessing about why is rather limited. Genetics is getting better.

Climate change happened alright, it was caused by a Comet striking the Ice Sheets which set fire to most of the continent and also caused huge continent wide floods. Ice chunks  that flew as far as the Carolinas  creating the "bays" and the Nebraska equivalents were secondary to the original strike. Both oval in shape pointing back to the Great Lakes strike area. Hard physical evidence is at the time frame, including craters, nano diamonds, fire soot and flood channels that are found all across the continent...Randall Carlson goes into great depth giving info on this, quoting peer reviewed papers from established scientific journals. Physicist Antonia Zamora presents evidence of this as well covering the Carolina and Nebraska bays. Zamora is a good place to start since his summation of the process is in one of his videos. Carlson and friends have presented over 180 hours thus far of in depth coverage. Check them out.

Shark scales and extinction...  3 things occur to me.  1) linear scales might generate less surface drag, allowing sharks with linear scales to get by with less food, or, having less drag would be faster and more able to get food.  But why at this time and not before?  2) Geometric scales might allow life forms to grow more on the sharks' skin, sort of like bottom fouling on a boat, exacerbating the difference on drag, but again, why at this time and not before?  I suppose maybe a new skin-fouling organism might have arisen at this time.  3)  The difference was not directly related to the scales themselves, but to some other difference, not visible, between linear-scaled sharks and those with geometric scales.  For example, perhaps a genetic difference between the two groups that made a difference in suceptability to a disease organism that arose at this time.  Or, it could have been something else altogether.
Hypotheses*

I’m a full supporter of what I’d call “Stressed into Extinction”, where multiple factors towards extinction played out at the same time. However, I also like to point out another kind of extinction: “Starved”.
Starved into extinction is a type of non-violent extinction where various food resources disappear, or becomes so scarce & non-abundant, that the species that do go extinct simply starved. Another variant is simply being outcompeted by more successful species where food is abundant, but other animals beat the ones that went extinct OR the food source adapted to not be an easy food source, thus the species that went extinct Starved out…

The megafauna mass extinction event 12k years ago coincides with the Younger Dryas period. (12,900-11,600 cal BP).
That is, a sudden and extreme temperature change, which lasted approx 1300 years. A hypothesis gaining traction is that the end of the younger dryas was triggered by a comet impact over the northern hemisphere. The impact apparently caused the 2km thick glaciers covering Canada to rapidly melt. I mean rapidly. The scablands in northern USA were allegedly caused by huge flows of melt water, washing away the countryside and decimating the megafauna. Watch Randall Carlson on one of Joe Rogans podcasts, brilliant stuff, he has studied the scablands for years. Also podcasts with Graham Hancock, he ties in the comet theory. Also goes on to explain the effect the comet had on human civilisation around the Mediterranean at the time as the comet appears to have broken up and impacted numerous places across the northern hemisphere. A recenty discovered depression under the Greenland icecaps indicate an impact site which dates to that time.

I'm starting to think extinction is part of the planet's life cycle.
Most sharks today are immune to natural disease. That could show that some plague ripped through their populations at some point, and only those with the most robust immune systems survived.

The likely reason why Africa is the only continent where megafauna still remain is because that is where modern humans evolved and the megafauna there had adaptations to cope with human hunting. Megafauna in other parts of the world didn't evolve alongside humans, so didn't have those adaptations.

I keep having to point this out because the proponents of the dominant narrative on the Pleistocene extinction just refuse to even MENTION that there is a THIRD theory that is now strong and still gathering evidence and is regarded by quite a few scientists as the leading contender, if not already proved. This is the so-called Younger Dryas Comet Impact Hypothesis. If you want a taste of how the evidence is shaping up you could not do better than check out the amazing video review of the ENTIRE scientific literature on this by Dr Martin Sweatman: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLftb0lOpSe9PvJhFKSueZV9Wrz4g1qRkr

It really is just TOO BAD that there seems to be a taboo on this. When it is mentioned, it is often scornful dismissal, something that is even evident in the scientific literature! You'd think that considering the experience with dinosaur extinction, where the very same thing happened, that the scientific community would learn to be more open to catastrophic possibilities, but it seems that they put the evidence bar WAY higher for those, which is not a proper scientific attitude.

I don't know if you give modern conservation efforts enough credit. You don't have to look very far to see major success stories for animals that were on the brink of collapse that are now reaching pest levels of population. To name a few; the white tailed or Virginia deer, the bald eagle, the red tailed hawk, the American antelope, all 6 subspecies of the American turkey, Buffalo, elk, Atlantic cod, Atlantic salmon, lake sturgeon, the Canadian goose, the American alligator, the brown, and black bear to name but a few. I know a lot of these animals are overlooked by a lot of people these days, and a lot of their success stories don't fit in certain narratives of ideologies that are in the foreground these days. However, I don't think it's fair to write off mankind as deplorable as a whole without at least offering a counter argument that not everything we touch turns to salt.

you're really gonna ignore the entire comet impact theory for the megafauna extinctions? with evidence spanning multiple continents? Humans appeared and suddenly mass murdered ALL megafauna? Thousands upon thounsands of prey species numbers, AND predators? From TWO continents, North and South America? Within an extremely short period of time? Please. Nowhere on earth is there an example of such a small population of humans causing that level of widespread extinction with stone age tools over such a huge area in such a short period of time. We have a black mat layer, just like the KT boundary. We have impact proxies found at multiple sites from North America to Syria. We have impact craters found in Greenland that were found under the Ice Sheet. We have possibly ice boulder fall back craters in the Carolinas and Nebraska, and massive flood evidence from Washington state to Maine. Like, it's not an insignificant amount of evidence, across multiple scientific fields. I'm actually really disappointed in SciShow, for the first time, on this one.

The evidence absolutely supports that Neanderthal populations absorbed into the general human population. The amount of genetics that anyone would have from ancestors 35K years ago is minimal. The other theories are based on colonialism, racism, and recency bias. Neanderthals and non-Neanderthals lived alongside each other in the Middle East for ten thousand years, so they wouldn’t have suddenly died off from disease. We just don’t have enough data to declare Neanderthals extinct. Besides, even if only one or two individual Neanderthals have had their genetic lines survive to the present day, they are not extinct. And for all we know, their languages and cultures continued far after their genetic distinction disappeared. This would be like saying Indigenous peoples are extinct or going extinct (which was a very popular belief until recently) when all they did was get assimilated. If a person is our ancestor, then they are not extinct, anymore than the non-Neanderthals who lived alongside them. We are no more related to them than their Neanderthal spouse.

The latest theory about Neanderthals is pretty interesting. Apparently, given that Neanderthals were much more robust and stockier in average compared to us, that meant that their caloric ingest was slightly bigger for their survival. That explains why Neanderthals never really became that widespread because bigger groups were unable to cope with difficult conditions that were very common in those times. Also, they relied more in their physical condition than us for hunting because Neanderthal equipment was more suited for melee attacks than our equipment that was more suited for medium to long distance hunting. You combine all of those factors and you get a pretty reasonable and interesting theory.

Source: one of the latest Eons episodes
More and more evidence has piled up over recent years, that humans arrived in North and South America long before megafauna went extinct.

For the megafauna extinction combination of climate change and isolations caused by humans over hunting in certain areas may have caused these species to be more vulnerable to resource competition with other megafauna, smaller and more adapted herbivores like deer and bison, as well as smaller gene pools may have led to their demise. Being a bigger mammal may make it harder for predators and the weather to kill you, but it means you’re a bigger target for humans, it takes longer for you to replenish your numbers due to longer gestation times which means low birth rates as well, and you need more food.

Another theory that I've learned about regarding the Neanderthal extinction centers on their caloric intake requirements.  From studying their bones, it has been estimated by scientists that they had a significantly higher muscle mass and metabolism, which then required  a significantly higher caloric intake than the average homo sapiens.  As a result, sapiens could survive with less food, which in colder periods (like the one where the Neanderthals disappeared from the fossil record) could easily make the difference over who survives and who doesn't.  If you couple this with some of the other complementary theories about this extinction, it sadly starts to look like a recipe for disaster for the Neanderthal. 😞
